SECTION 1 â€“ INTRODUCTION TO TOOLS, EQUIPMENT & WORKSHOP SAFETY
1.1 Understanding the Job Before Selecting Tools
Before any tool is picked up, a worker must be able to explain:
Which material is being worked on
Which tool is suitable and WHY
What documentation applies (SOP, JSA, drawing, job card)
This builds the â€œcompetent worker mindsetâ€:
Know the job â†’ plan the job â†’ choose the right tool â†’ use the tool safely.
require students to justify tool choice and explain â€œwhy this tool is best for this jobâ€.
You need to cut a piece of 1.2 mm sheet metal. Which tool do you select and why?
Workers must demonstrate they can correctly interpret:
finding notes on holes, bends, tolerances
matching tools to required operations (cutting, marking, drilling, shaping)
until they can clearly explain what the finished task must look like.
include â€œidentify correct documentâ€, â€œinterpret simple workshop drawingâ€, and â€œfollow instructions in logical orderâ€.
require students to read and follow job instructions.
The drawing shows a 10 mm hole must be drilled. What must you check before choosing a drill bit?
1.3 Following Workplace SOPs and Workflow Documents
Workers must be taught to follow documentation EXACTLY as it appears, matching the company SOPs used in industry.
correct tool retrieval and check-out procedures
using tools only for approved tasks
returning tools clean and stored correctly
reporting missing, damaged or faulty tools
recording work completed on a job sheet
following sequencing (e.g., mark â†’ clamp â†’ cut â†’ deburr â†’ inspect)
require evidence that the student follows correct workflow order.
require students to read and follow tool and equipment SOPs.
Why must you follow the tool SOP instead of â€œusing your own methodâ€?
Version control helps workers ensure they are using:
â€œJOB CARD â€“ Revision C â€“ Updated cutter size for hole.â€
Why could using an outdated document cause an unsafe situation?

w:r.w:t: Workers must plan the safest and most efficient order of operations, which mirror standard engineering industry workflows.
Set up work area and clamp material
include â€œsequence of safe work stepsâ€ and â€œpreparation before tool useâ€.
use a sequence of operations to produce project to job specifications.
Why must clamping be done before cutting or drilling?
1.7 Identifying Information Needed Before Selecting Tools
Workers must gather the following information from job documents:
material type (steel, aluminium, plastic, sheet metal)
type + size of cuts, holes, or shapes
require students to match tools to materials and tasks.
require students to read project plans to gain
What two factors affect which file a worker should choose?

SECTION 2 â€“ WHS REQUIREMENTS FOR HAND & POWER TOOL USE

Hand and power tools can only be safely used when students understand how WHS laws, site procedures and safe work practices apply in the workshop. This section supports the legal and procedural expectations found in standard engineering
Before ANY tool use, workers must wear the correct PPE. This protects against injury and reduces exposure to hazards such as noise, sharp edges, sparks, heat and debris.
Essential PPE in manufacturing/engineering workshops includes:

Before selecting a tool or beginning work, workers must identify hazards such as:

require students to identify hazards before starting tasks.

2.3 Risk Controls Using the Hierarchy of Control
Workers must understand how risk controls work in a workshop. Examples include:
Removing broken tools from the workshop
Use a safer tool (e.g., hand snips instead of angle grinder for thin sheet metal)

Even though full industrial JSAs are not always required in classrooms, the principles apply:
read the hazard controls for the task
identify risks associated with each step
thinking about the hazards of each step
communicating findings into a JSA document
similar to the JSA but used for high-risk manufacturing and engineering tasks
What is the purpose of a JSA and SWMS?
require students to follow a safe work sequence.

SECTION 3 â€“ HAND TOOLS: SELECTION, INSPECTION & SAFE USE.
Hand tools are used in nearly every engineering task. Workers must be able to choose the right tool for the job, inspect it for faults, use it safely, and maintain it according to workshop standards.
Choosing the correct tool is essential for:
which tool is correct for this job?

secure material using a vice or clamp

How to use Basic Metal Hand Tools!
students to safely use hand tools.
Why do you apply pressure only on the forward stroke when filing?
Workers must maintain tools at a basic workshop level, including:
using correct grinding and honing technique
Most sharpening/maintenance is performed by trained staff, but all workers need to understand:
what a sharp edge looks like
when a tool is too dull to use
how to maintain a clean cutting surface
require tools to be returned â€œclean and ready for the next userâ€.
What is the purpose of using a file card?
Workers must be able to perform
adjustments to ensure hand tools operate correctly. These adjustments do not involve advanced repairs â€” they are simple, routine workshop tasks.
Adjusting pivot tension on tin snips
Realigning jaws on pliers if slightly off
Tightening screws on marking tools (square, compass)
Oiling hinged joints for smooth movement

SECTION 4 â€“ POWER TOOLS: OPERATION, SETUP, PRE-START CHECKS & CONTROLS

Power tools allow workers to complete tasks faster and with higher precision â€” but they also introduce greater risk. This section ensures students understand safe setup, correct operation, inspection requirements, and fault-reporting procedures.
4.1 Types of Power Tools Used in Manufacturing & Engineering

Workers must NEVER operate a power tool until a full pre-start inspection is completed.
Check cord for cuts, frays or exposed wiring
RCD (safety switch) must be used if portable
Key or chuck removed before operation
assess a studentâ€™s ability to â€œ
Why must you never use a grinder disc with a chip or crack in it?
Workers must be able to demonstrate correct:
keep others clear of the work area
let the tool reach full speed
apply steady pressure â€” donâ€™t force
allow tool to do the work
require correct technique and body positioning.

w:r.w:t: Guards MUST be in place on all rotating or blade tools.
grinder guard covers correct section of disc
cut-off saw blade guard retracts smoothly
pedestal drill chuck guard is lowered during drilling
tool rests on bench grinders are set correctly

operate correctly. These adjustments do not involve advanced repairs â€” they are simple, routine workshop tasks.
Adjusting tool rests on a bench grinder

Adjusting angle/mitre settings on cut-off saws

w:r.w:t: Most introductory metal/engineering workshops allow only low-risk powered tools. Workers must follow strict SOPs. Examples include:
Secure the workpiece using a vice or clamp
Select the correct drill bit for the material
Hold the drill firmly with two hands
Fit the correct disc (cutting or grinding) for the task and for cracks before use

MAINTENANCE, TAG-OUT, FAULTS & REPLACEMENT OF CONSUMABLES
Maintaining tools is a core skill in engineering workshops. Workers are expected to keep tools in safe working condition, identify faults early, and follow correct reporting and isolation procedures.
Poor maintenance is one of the most common causes of tool failures, workshop injuries and damaged workpieces.
Why is regular maintenance important in a workshop?
why maintenance tasks matter. This helps them make safer decisions and avoid damaging tools.
Power tools generate heat when overloaded
Dull bits/discs cause heat because they don't cut properly
Incorrect tools lead to slipping, poor control and injury
Cracks, chips or wear reduce strength
Faults grow quickly at high speeds (grinders, drills)
Tool rests, guards and vice jaws must be correctly aligned
Incorrect alignment â†’ poor accuracy or tool kickback
Why does a dull drill bit cause overheating?
Basic Tool Care: Cleaning, Lubrication & Adjustment
Workers must demonstrate correct care methods for both hand and power tools.
Wipe metal surfaces to prevent rust
Light oil for moving metal parts
Use correct lubricants (no WD40 on electrics)
Adjust tool rests on bench grinders
Maintain correct belt tension on sanders
Why should ventilation slots on a power tool be kept clean?
ensure disc is correct type (cutting or grinding)
match disc RPM rating to tool
ensure arrow direction matches grinder rotation
Which disc is used for cutting metal?
What must match between the grinder and the disc?
Why remove the chuck key before drilling?
What must you check before fitting a new grinder disc?
To meet workshop standards and general SOP expectations, workers must:
document when discs, bits or belts are changed
notify supervisor/teacher when stock is low
on â€œreporting problems with tools or equipmentâ€.
Why must changes to consumables (like discs or bits) be recorded?
MANUFACTURING and ENGINEERING â€œTASK 2 â€“ RIGHT TOOL, RIGHT JOBâ€ WORKBOOK
STORING, SECURING & SHUTTING DOWN TOOLS & WORK AREAS
Correct shutdown and storage procedures reduce accidents, prevent damage to tools, and support a professional workshop culture.
A workshop must always be left in a
assessment assess a studentâ€™s ability to leave the work area clean, and tools stored correctly.
Why must tools be cleaned and put away immediately after use?
Workers must be able to demonstrate step-by-step safe shutdown:
Wait for moving parts to stop
â€” unplug or switch off at isolator
Return tool to correct storage location
What should you do before leaving a machine unattended?
students must shut down pedestal drills, grinders and hand-held tools correctly.
